Le Monde enters Gaza City, an ocean of ruins emptied of its people
subhead: Le Monde's Jerusalem correspondent entered the Palestinian urban area for a few hours on Friday, October 3, under escort from the Israel Defense Forces (IDF). The territory, largely destroyed by airstrikes and bulldozers, was utterly deserted, with nearly all residents having fled south within the enclave.
byline: By Luc Bronner (Gaza City, special correspondent)

title: Bad Bunny brings Puerto Rican pride to the Super Bowl amid MAGA backlash

title: USAID contraceptives in Belgium: 'This stock in perfect condition must be seized to meet urgent needs'
subhead: Four legal experts argue that Belgium has the legal basis and political legitimacy to seize the stockpile of contraceptives that the Trump administration is threatening to destroy.

title: Why foreigners love France but struggle with the French
subhead: While France captivates with its culture and lifestyle, the French, frequently caricatured as arrogant and impolite, often have a poor reputation. This ambivalence raises questions about the roots of anti-French sentiment abroad.

Thomas Piketty: 'If Europe does not urgently give up its love of free trade, it risks an unprecedented social and industrial disaster'
subhead: Europe should impose tariffs as a sort of tax on the CO₂ generated by the transportation of goods and to counter the damaging effects of Chinese dumping, writes the French economist.

title: At Cédric Jubillar's trial, a snapshot of cruelty
subhead: Cathy M., the then partner of Delphine Jubillar's lover, found out about their relationship before Jubillar disappeared. Before the court, Cathy M., who was quickly written off as a suspect, had to explain the messages she sent to her rival.

title: Former American diplomat Robert Malley: 'Trump's Gaza plan offers more ambiguities and potential pitfalls than clear answers'
subhead: In an interview with Le Monde, Robert Malley, who participated in peace negotiations between Israel and Palestine under Bill Clinton, Barack Obama and Joe Biden, sees Donald Trump's plan as yet another attempt that fails to take history into account. In particular, he questions the relevance of the two-state solution.
